üá¨üáß Friends, let me comment on one issue that is currently relevant and that bothers me a lot. Specifically, I am talking about such childish monument wars, which have unfortunately increased in recent years among slavic peoples under the influence of events in some western states, where the demolition of monuments of important personalities has became a national sport during last 10 years. The latest victim of that was in Poland the statue of soviet and polish marshal and later polish minister of defence Konstantin Rokossovsky, who helped liberate a significant part of eastern Europe and Poland itself from german occupation. However, I am not just talking only about this case, there are from all sides more than enough examples of various demolitions of monuments and renaming of streets out on purpose to neighboring slavic nations. I understand the issues of a certain historical and national context, as well as the enormous complexity of relations between some eastern european nations. I completely understand that, for example, the Poles do not want and do not need statues of Lenin, or people like Marchlewski or Tukhachevsky, who waged war against Poland, but was it really necessary to vandalize the statue of marshal Rokossovsky? Or, if I look at the russian side, was it really necessary to issue a recent stupid statement that the events in Katyn did not happen? Or on the southern wing of the slavic world - is it really necessary to rename the streets, which are named after the neighboring slavic nations, as they plan in Belgrade and as they did before in Bosnia and Croatia?

Of course, none of this is necessary. I've had enough and I'm saying directly - we Slavs have 2 big problems. The first is such ultraliberalism, through which various self-destructive nonsenses from the West is pushed towards us, and the second is similarly dangerous ultranationalism, whose followers try to unleash hatred among slavic peoples through similar actions. I support traditionalism, I support the healthy national proud and patriotism of all slavic nations, I am against globalism and liberalism, but on the other side I unequivocally reject chauvinism. We only harm ourselves with that, instead of cooperating, we argue and fight with each other, while someone else benefits from it. We are interested in childish fights between ourselves, and in the meantime others make from the many central and eastern european countries their economic colonies, sources of cheap labor, markets for their schlock, and places to export various self-destructive ideologies.

In conclusion, I say that I respect all those who fought against nazi Germany; I respect Rokossovsky (pictured) and other soviet military commanders and soldiers, I respect B√≥r-Komorowski and polish patriots in the same way, and I also respect heroes from all the nations of Czechoslovakia and Yugoslavia. Of course, I realize that many of these people have made mistakes or downright bad things (if we look at the Warsaw Uprising, for example, Rokossovsky made the mistake if he waited waiting and did not help the uprising, and Bor-Komorowski made the mistake if he prohibited communication with the Red army under strict punishments), but I think their positive significance regarding the defeat of nazism goes beyond these negative episodes. Please think about it and finally end this cycle of mutual animosities...

I will be happy if you write me your opinions on this topic in the comments. I will be glad also for dissenting opinions, I just ask you all for decency and mutual respect. This post is here to provoke discussion, not the fight. Thank you.

üá¨üáß Photograph of women from the south slavic ethnic group called Gorantsi in their traditional costumes. Gorantsi or Gorani people are an interesting ethnic group, which mainly inhabits some areas in southern Serbia (Gora region in the Kosovo province), but in addition, we can find them in northern Albania and northwestern Macedonia. There are about 30-50 thousand of them and from the ethnic point of view they consider themselves mainly as Serbs or as Gorantsi as an independent nationality (a smaller part as Bosniaks, Macedonians or Bulgarians), however they differ from Serbs and from the most of other mentioned nationalities mainly in one thing - during the Ottoman occupation of the Balkans they accepted islam and together with Bosniaks, macedonian Torbesh people or bulgarian Pomaks are thus one of the south slavic ethnic groups they confess this religion, which is the basis for some of their different customs and traditions. However, it must be said that even though they are muslims, they still preserve many south slavic christian traditions, for example, they celebrate Djurdjevden (St. George's Day) or Slava (Family Patron Saint's Day) ‚ò™Ô∏èüá∑üá∏

It is interesting that Gorantsi are skilled in many crafts, traditionally excel in confectionery and bakery, and are often referred in this regard as the best in the Balkans. It is known that many members of the their diaspora in Western Europe are the owners of renowned confectioneries.

We write about this ethnic group mainly because, like the Lusatian Sorbs, they deserve our increased attention, as they face a significant threat to their ethnic and cultural identity. As we all know, Kosovo in southern Serbia is currently being occupied by the U√áK terrorist organization and its foreign allies contrary to international law. Representatives of the Kosovo quasi-state do not hide their anti-slavic racism, and many of them aim for ethnic cleansing of the territory from all non-albanian elements. They use various more or less violent methods to do so - while the orthodox Serbs are forced to leave the country by escalating violence, the muslim Gorantsi are forcibly albanized and forced to renounce their slavic language and heritage. The slavic world should be aware of these problems and strongly oppose the albanization of the Gorantsi, as well as we have to strongly oppose the expulsing of Kosovo Serbs or the germanization of the Lusatian Sorbs...

Jage≈Ç≈Ço and lithuanian prince Vytautas, supported by czech troops under commanders Jan ≈Ωi≈æka of Trocnov and Jan Sokol of Lamberk üá®üáø and also supported by units of some russian principalities üá∑üá∫ and by mongolian-tatarian troop üá≤üá≥, defeated the Order of German Knights and its allies gathered from all corners of today's Germany and ended its expansion in eastern Europe and baltic space.

It is no exaggeration to say that this was one of the most important victories in the history of the Slavs and the Baltics, which, among other things, saved large areas of Eastern Europe from the fate of violent germanization, to which had previously succumbed the Polabian Slavs and the original baltic Prussians ...

üá¨üáß Dear friends!
Today we have a significant day in the Czech republic, when we commemorate the coming of slavic apostles Saint Constantine (Cyril) and Saint Methodius from Solun to Great Moravia. These two brothers not only brought christianity to Great Moravia on request of the prince Rastislav, but also at the same time promoted old slavonic church language (made from slavic dialects from the region of city Solun) as a official worship language (besides latin, greek and hebrew) and created a script called glagolitic, later perfected on cyrillic. All this was an important step towards reducing the influence of the Frankish empire in today's bohemian - moravian - slovakian space.

Today they are considered to be the holy co - patrons of Europe and also the patrons of Moravia.

Today we generally commemorate not only the origin of christianity in the Czech lands, but also one of the beginnings of our own national identity üá®üáø

We wish you to celebrate this holiday in a pleasant way and at the same time that all the people in Moravia, Bohemia, Silesia, Slovakia and other slavic Homelands today remembered the meaning of this important day...

P.S .: We do not enforced you christianity, we only represents our slavic culture as a whole, including its christian part ‚õ™Ô∏è

üá¨üáß Our series about the events of the end of World War II, in which we will remember the struggle of the nations of the USSR, Poland, Czechoslovakia, Yugoslavia and others for the liberation from the german occupation, will be initiated with an iconic photography depicted soviet soldier who, after years of hardship in battles, hangs a flag on the roof of the Reichstag building, because yesterday we remembered the anniversary, when Berlin was conquered and its crew capitulated officially.

Berlin, built originally on slavic settlements, according which are still names some city districts (for example Spandau, originally Spandava or Pankow), was the focal point of Hitler's megalomaniac plans. It would to be renamed to Germania and become the capital of Europe, but of Europe, where there would be no place for the Slavs and Jews. However, the importance for future events attributed to it not only the nazis, but also the Allies, who knew, that its conquest was crucial for the fall of the Third reich. Soviet command drafted plans for an offensive against Berlin in 1944, but was put into practice in the following year. At the beginning of April 1945 the town was already surrounded by the 1st Belarusian front of marshal Zhukov, the 2nd Belarusian front of marshal Rokossovsky, the 1st Ukrainian front of marshal Konev and also by 200 000 soldiers of the Polish army. The loop began to be tighten and tighten. The nazis to defend themselves also called to the battle 12 year olds children and 70 year olds seniors. On 14th April the Red army began to attack the city and slowly, but surely, advanced to the center. The situation of the Germans was already hopeless, nazi criminals gradually began to leave the city and fled either to northern Germany, which was still in their hands or to the west to surrender to the american and the british forces, because they were afraid of soviet retribution for their bestial crimes committed in eastern Europe. Hitler himself committed suicide in his bunker on 30th April and the entire Berlin garrison surrendered on 2nd May. Elsewhere, however, still continued fights, in the Protectorate of Bohemia and Moravia on 5th May ‚Äúthe bloody dog‚Äù ‚Äã‚ÄãKarl Herman Frank threatened to the radio, that he would drown every rebellion against Germans in the czech blood. A few days after the conquest of Berlin soviet radists captured the call of Prague for help and marshal Konev decided to go with his army to help. But about it in the next posts...

üá¨üáß These days we commemorate one of the most terrible events of modern history, namely the genocide of Armenians, Greeks of Asia Minor, Assyrians and Aramaics, whose became victims of massacre planned and organized by the turkish authorities to ethnically cleanse Asia Minor and other areas of the former Ottoman empire. Millions of men, women and children were murdered in a particularly brutal and torturous way, that still shocks the world by its inhumanity.

Maybe you're wondering why we put something like that on the page about Slavs or what does it actually have to do with Slavs? Let's start from the beginning. Nations like Armenians, Greeks, Georgians and others have many things in common with us. Together with us Slavs they share our living space in central, eastern and southeastern Europe, our history is intertwined and also through the heritage of the Byzantine empire, our culture or at least a significant part of it is connected. We also have in common that for centuries we have experienced similar oppression. Like the nations mentioned above, we Slavs were dragged into slavery by the millions (it is estimated that more than 8 million Slavs were dragged into tatar or turkish slavery), we faced a dark period when our countries were completely wiped off the map of the world, and when foreigners tried to destroy and colonize our countries. While the Greeks and Armenians gradually watched as their ethnic territory in Asia Minor was forcibly turkicised, so we Slavs had to watch as large areas of the Polabian Slavs changed into the germanized territory of Prussia and then eastern Germany. These genocides reached their peak in the 20th century, at first around 1915 by several waves of the genocide of the Armenians, Greeks and other orthodox nations of the Ottoman empire and then during World War II by the german extermination war against eastern nations, especially Slavs and Jews. However, few people know, that these two massacres were in many ways interconnected. It is well known, that Adolf Hitler knew about the armenian genocide during the First World War, and that he and other german nazis were inspired by it. One of Hitler‚Äôs statements about it was preserved to these days - when they asked him what the world public would say about his plans to liquidate tens of millions of people from central and eastern Europe, he just cynically replied: "And who remember the massacre of Armenians today?" However, he was not the only one in Germany. As is known during the First World War, the Ottoman empire was one of the Central Powers. However, it did not do very well on the battlefields, so german advisers came to the country, gradually gained great influence and soon controlled the whole ottoman army. They knew about all massacres, but they did nothing to stop it. Some armenian historical sources even claim, that it was the german advisers, who provoked the genocide, because they purposefully instilled to ottoman politicians and officers the idea, that the orthodox nations of Asia Minor are unreliable and tends to cooperate with the Russian empire, and therefore they should be disposed. Theoretically, there could exist people in the german armed forces, who took part in the genocide of the Armenians, the Greeks of Asia Minor and the Assyrians, as well as in the genocide of the Slavs and Jews.

So let‚Äôs remember these days the victims of the massacre in 1915, and at the same time let‚Äôs remember the victims of the many genocides and injustices, to which we Slavs have been exposed over the centuries (forced germanization, turkish occupation of Balkan, devshirme, enslavement of slavic people by Tatars, Teutonic order, Drang nach osten, Generalplan Ost, Hunger Plan etc.). At the same time, we should inspire by Armenians, Greeks and Assyrians and together agree on a day, which would commemorate the victims of the genocide of the Slavs, to which fell victims tens of millions of people...

üá¨üáß Recently, on the czech internet has appeared one article, in which scientists from Masaryk University in Brno warn against the increase in the influence of slavic and panslavic ideas in public and virtual space (you can read article HERE üëâüèª https://www.idnes.cz/zpravy/domaci/brno-vedci-univerzity-ruska-slovanska-nacionalisticka-propaganda-orientace-rusko-zkoumani.A200410_080535_domaci_kane). Therefore, they intend to monitor the internet and social networks in the next years and to gather information about the people, sites and webpages, which promote slavic ideas. They even received a grant from the state for this "research". Because we are one of the largest slavic sites on czech social networks, we would like to react. 

In essence, both the article and the above - mentioned initiative present an increase in interest in slavic ideas as something wrong, and of course subliminally underlines the idea, that people dealing with slavic ideas are automatically servants of some foreign power. We do not like this ideologically motivated labeling. It is a manifestation of the intolerance of people, who present themselves as democrats, but who are not really willing to accept a different opinions. They try to push out from public space everything, what they consider not sufficiently pro - European, pro-western and liberal and try to discredit their opponents. However, we say, that slavic traditionalism is a legitimate political and social direction, which is a full-fledged alternative to liberal globalism, and it is our democratic rights to express this position. No one has the right to call us, without any evidence, as spies of foreign powers or as propagators of radical propaganda. We are not doing anything wrong or anything unethical, we are first of all patriots searching for our roots and trying to foster friendship between the peoples of central and eastern Europe on the basis of what we have in common. In our project we try to treat all slavic nations fairly and objectively; from a political point of view, we are not taking side of any state.

The picture we attach to this post is a proof, that history is constantly repeating. It is a scene from the film adaptation of the novel by czech writer Jaroslav Ha≈°ek, which takes place during the First World War. The film perfectly captures the paranoia of the austro - hungarian military officers, whose obsession in hunting of supposed russian agents reaches absurd proportions (you can play this scene HERE üëâüèª https://youtu.be/zF8O1t34B7Y). Unfortunately, we live in a similar times today, but it is all the more reason why it is important to preserve and to support slavic ideas. Therefore we will continue in our project Slavs in pictures and poetry despite all adversities...

‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî
üá¨üáß On the eve of the 75th anniversary of the end of World War II, which we will celebrate this May, the mayor of Prague 6 abused the current situation of the ban of all public gatherings due to coronavirus, and removed the statue of marshal Konev, who was involved in liberating Czechoslovakia from the german occupation.

Unfortunately, there have always been politicians in history, who could not offer a quality program to people and therefore invented pseudo - problems, on which they build their political careers. It is similar in this case. Instead of helping the citizens as much as possible in times of present crisis, the city mayor and councilors spend time and considerable money from the city coffers to demolish a statue, around which they had previously artificially unleashed an affair on. Now that it is complete, they are somewhere in the peace and safety of their homes, where they feel the taste of their small victory. At the same time, the safety of their homes was won by people like marsal Konev, whose legacy they dehonest. They have not realized yet, that due to the method of execution their momentary ‚Äúvictory‚Äù has a taste of small - mindedness, embarrassment and turpitude.

In addition, one more thing is bothering us - attempts to review the outcome of World War II are becoming a dangerous trend politically promoted by many pro - western politicians and pro - german activists. We patriots are watching it all with concern. While the statue of marshal, thanks to whose share on the defeat of nazism we can exist as a nation, lies in the dust on the ground with a noose on its neck, so especially in the borderland, various dubious monuments and initiatives grow like mushrooms after rain. One such is the recently renewed quasivalhala built in 1944 for fallen sudeten german SS soldiers in the Jizera Mountains (more HERE üëâüèª https://www.lidovky.cz/cestovani/v-jizerskych-horach-je-k-videni-nacisticky-memorial-undoubtedly-is-the-symbol-third-rise-pise-historian.A190905_123438_cestopisy_vag).

In conclusion, we finish our post with the words well known among czechoslovakian anti - nazi resistance: ‚ÄúPeople beware!‚Äù, because at this special time, vigilance is certainly appropriate. Again, many dark anti - czech and anti - slavic streams are emerging from the past, which more or less covertly want to assert their interests. Rewriting of history is their first step. If we will do nothing, so we can expect, that maybe some activists will build a monument to Konrad Henlein or Karel Herman Frank (note: german nazis, which participated a lot on the suffering of czech people during WW2) in near future. If you consider it unrealistic, remember that we have already renewed the above - mentioned SS quazivalhala, or that one peripheral part of Prague is going to build a monument to the Vlasov army, ie collaborators with the nazis, who participated in the massacre of residents in moravian village Sala≈°. Hospitals, schools with children, radio and television buildings, trains, refugee convoys and factories of consumer industry in strategic point of view strategically of little importance were bombed. The bombing of Yugoslavia is one example of a war crime that has not yet been punished. A crime committed by people of questionable moral profiles such as Javier Solana, Bill Clinton, Wesley Clark, Madelaine Albright, and others, who are not ashamed to bombard civilians with banned weapons for their economic interests and political careers. Hopefully, once the overall geopolitical situation in Europe and in the whole world changes, these individuals will be justly punished for what they have committed...

üá¨üáß Today we commemorate one sad anniversary in slavic history, specifically the anniversary of the Martovski pogrom (March pogrom), when in 2004 started massive attacks of Albanians against Serbs in southern serbian province Kosovo. The fanatized crowds were driving through the streets and during the total inactivity of present NATO troops attacked the Serbs and in some cases also the Albanians, who refused to join these riots. The result of the pogrom was a massacre in which 19 people were killed and more than a thousand injured. 730 serbian homes were destroyed and 36 orthodox churches, monasteries and other cultural or religious sites (some of them on the UNESCO World heritage list) were destroyed. More than 4,000 people had to flee their homes. The sacred land of Slavs was desecrated and, with the help of cynical western politicians and their lickspittles, was created a "state" Kosovo, on which thanks to privatization agreements with islamists and drug barons from U√áK, american politicians and generals earned great money. Meanwhile Hashim Tha√ßi or Ramush Haradinaj from this heart of serbian nation have made a dysfunctional territory, where illegal trade with narcotics and human organs is rampant, and where people connected to the Islamic state shamelessly operate...

The picture shows one of the serbian orthodox churches, which was destroyed during this rampage.

NEVER FORGET! KOSOVO IS SERBIA! üá∑üá∏

Recently, provincial elections took place in Saxony and Brandenburg and as part of an election campaign, the AfD (Alternative f√ºr Deutschland; german nationally oriented party) posted posters in lusatian sorbian language with the slogan "≈òeƒçe i kultury zd≈∫er≈æeƒá!" (in english ‚ÄúTo preserve language and culture!‚Äù). It was the only political party, which presents posters in Lusatia also in the language of the native people.

And we'd like to ask you, what do you think about that? Do you believe, that this is after several centuries the first step of german nationalist politics in the recognition of the slavic heritage of whole eastern Germany and Lusatia especially, or do you consider it a pre - election trick and a false promise, which no one would be interested to fulfill after the elections? Please, write us your opinion to the comments, we will be glad for it...

P.S.: As czech patriots we perceive many AfD activities as very problematic, especially the active support of organizations such as the Sudetendeutsche Landsmanschaft and the german imperial mindset of many members and officials. It is also one of the reasons why we do not know, what attitude to take. The gesture is nice, but how much sincerity is in it?

üá¨üáß On these days (29th - 30th September) we remember the sad event in the history of Czechoslovakia....

Exactly 81 years ago a conference of representatives of nazi Germany (Adolf Hitler), fascist Italy (Benito Mussolini), France (Edouard Daladier) and Great Britain (Neville Chamberlain) were summoned to Munich to solve the so - called "Sudeten question" in the areas of the czechoslovakian border region. The conference was the culmination of the previous events of a century - old dispute between Czechs and the czech Germans, who came in the middle ages to the territory, which has always been ours, as guests at the invitation of the some czech kings, but as humble guests they behaved only sometimes and only some of them. With the establishment of Czechoslovakia a large number of them never reconciled, even though Czechoslovakia as one of the few countries with such a large german minority provided them with all the linguistic and national freedom. In the first CS republic there were thousands of german schools, german radio and the press and in the late twenties their ministers were in our government. But it was not enough for them. 

Since the beginning of the thirties in german - speaking areas began to spread nazi ideas and the result was anti - czech and anti - slavic moods spreaded mostly through the Sudeten german party, which resulted in several serious incidents, when czech families living in mostly german - speaking areas were attacked and lynched, the example is incident in little town Habartov. Czechoslovakia tried to reconcile with them, but the demands of the sudeten Germans led by the nazi Konrad Henlein (who paradoxically, despite their hatred towards the Czechs, was half Czech, because they had a czech mother) were stepping up. Nazi propaganda sent to the world false and fictional reports of alleged terror against the Germans in Czechoslovakia. The Western Powers, which were the guarantors of the establishment of our slavic state, gradually began to cling to the nazi side. In 1938 the situation was rampant  and Czechoslovakia was forced to mobilize, because of nazi military maneuvers. Germany was secretly sent to our territories members of SS, SA and Freikorps, who attacked and killed czech gendarmes and border guards. 

The Western Powers decided to send to Czechoslovakia Lord Runciman's mission to recognize, what is happening in the Czechoslovakia border areas. But he was totally incompetent and unilaterally focused, he was not interested in the situation and essentially his only activities were visits to the spectacles of sudeten german pronazi aristocrats. According to it his final report looked like. In September 1938 Hitler had at the NSDAP congress his fanatical speech full of hatred towards Czechoslovakia, which led to riots and several local uprisings in our border regions. In response to these events a conference of the aforementioned representatives was convened in Munich. The night of 29 and 30 September became the night of treachery. The Western powers, with whom we had allied treaties, to whom we looked up and in whom we hoped in our struggle for freedom and democracy, preyed us to the nazis and forced us to surrender our territory to Germany. On the following day the german military units, which was prepared before, came into the border region enthusiastically celebrated by a large part (not all) of sudeten Germans, who with the Wehrmacht, the SS and the Gestapo began to forcibly expel their czech neighbors. The victims also became german anti - fascists, who fled the from Germany because of nazis or the czech Germans, who were loyal to Czechoslovakia. There was also a refend, in which most Germans agreed to join Germany. So the dark epoch of our Homeland began, which was completed by the nazi occupation of our entire territory...

And we'd like to ask you, what do you think about that? Do you believe, that this is after several centuries the first step of german nationalist politics in the recognition of the slavic heritage of whole eastern Germany and Lusatia especially, or do you consider it a pre - election trick and a false promise, which no one would be interested to fulfill after the elections? Please, write us your opinion to the comments, we will be glad for it...

P.S.: As czech patriots we perceive many AfD activities as very problematic, especially the active support of organizations such as the Sudetendeutsche Landsmanschaft and the german imperial mindset of many members and officials. It is also one of the reasons why we do not know, what attitude to take. The gesture is nice, but how much sincerity is in it?

üá¨üáß Today and tomorrow (8th May and 9th May) in the slavic countries we commemorate the anniversary of the end of the last battles of World War 2 in Europe. We think it is important to remind the the great sacrifice of the Slavs in the fight against german nazism and to bow down to the immense courage of our grandfathers, who by their love for the Homeland, by their determination and by their will to live, have overcome a powerful enemy. So on these days let's take some time and remember the soldiers and ordinary people of all nations of the east and west, who, in this conflict, laid their lives for us and our future. If time permits, stop for a moment at a memorial and think for a moment about those, who have fallen here and at least in thoughts honor their memory, because if they were not there, we would probably not even be here ...

Love for life, which is typical for Slavs, will always overwhelm the dark cult of death and hate then represented by nazi Germany and its black order of SS...
